Skin (or mucous membrane) biopsy with direct immunofluorescence examination is used to confirm the diagnosis of autoimmune bullous disease or to suggest a non-autoimmune cause of bullous disease. If the direct immunofluorescence test is negative, it can rule out the diagnosis of autoimmune bullous dermatosis and point to other causes of bullous lesions. It can also be used to distinguish between the group of sub-epidermal dermatoses (pemphigoid for autoimmune causes) and intra-epidermal dermatoses (pemphigus group for autoimmune causes).

question.title: What can a negative direct immunofluorescence test result indicate in the diagnosis of bullous dermatosis?
question.description: A question about the diagnostic value of direct immunofluorescence examination in bullous dermatosis

option_a.title: Only autoimmune causes of bullous dermatosis
option_a.description: A plausible but incorrect option that might confuse the respondent

option_b.title: Only non-autoimmune causes of bullous dermatosis
option_b.description: A plausible but incorrect option that might confuse the respondent

option_c.title: Both autoimmune and non-autoimmune causes of bullous dermatosis
option_c.description: A distractor option that might confuse the respondent due to its logical coherence

option_d.title: Neither autoimmune nor non-autoimmune causes of bullous dermatosis
option_d.description: The correct option that accurately reflects the diagnostic value of a negative direct immunofluorescence test result

correct_option.title: D
